title: Trophy for FIFA Women Champions Cup unveiled at Brentford | Richmond and Twickenham Times
body_text:
Pupils at a Brentford school were given an exclusive first glimpse of the FIFA Women’s Champions Cup™ trophy by former England international and Arsenal legend Alex Scott and World Cup-winning coach Jill Ellis.
The new silverware was unveiled just days before the start of the tournament, which will see the first women’s intercontinental club champions crowned in London on February 1.
Scott, an ambassador for the 2026 edition of the tournament, said: "It’s incredible to see the first-ever FIFA Women’s Champions Cup come to life here in London, bringing together champions from every continent to compete on a truly global stage."
Pupils met Scott and Ellis during the event, held at a school near Brentford Stadium, which will host the semi-finals on January 28.
Ellis, who coached the US Women’s National Team to two World Cup titles, said: "It was a pleasure to spend time with the children and witness their excitement as they saw the trophy up close. I can’t wait to see them in the stadium in just a few days’ time.

"As a former coach, I firmly believe we must seize every opportunity to engage with the younger generation and share the values and magic of our sport.
"This incredible new tournament will help inspire a new generation of passionate women’s football supporters – girls and boys alike – and support the game’s continued evolution and growth."
The children took part in a Q&A with Scott and Ellis, received official tournament merchandise, and had the chance to interact with the newly unveiled trophy. They will also attend one of the semi-final matches at Brentford Stadium.
On January 28, Concacaf champions Gotham FC (USA) will face SC Corinthians (Brazil) at 12:30 GMT, followed by UEFA Women’s Champions League holders Arsenal Women FC (England) against CAF Women’s Champions League winners ASFAR (Morocco) at 18:00 GMT.
The third-place play-off and final will take place on February 1, at Arsenal Stadium in London.
The trophy is designed to reflect the core values of the new competition—global unity and excellence in women’s club football—and incorporates maps of each participating nation into its design.
